rename.to: How is isDirectoryContaining supposed to work?

body:
The javadoc indicates the syntax follows https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/nio/file/FileSystem.html#getPathMatcher-java.lang.String- which is not straightforward I do agree bu that's the java jdk api (hence the other assertions with a `Predicate` where you can programmatically expresses the filter).

It looks like the `**` syntax (or the predicate) is not traversing sub-directories but only look at the directory first level content which sounds reasonable (I need more time to find out if it's a bug or not). Did you expect the assertion to traverse subdirectories recursively?
Indeed I was expecting a recursive traverse assertion
@scordio any naming suggestion for the recursive assertion?
I would tend to avoid the boolean parameter (solution 1) and to prefer 3; the name in 2 does not sound correct in English but I'm not a native speaker ;)

Hello,

> Thanks @ebundy, let's implement no3:
> 
> ```java
> assertThat(outputDirectory).isDirectoryRecursivelyContaining("glob:**.java");
> ```

You are welcome. I have just examined the current API around `isDirectoryContaining()`. 
To be consistent and symmetric with the current API we should define 4 API methods both for `FileAssert`. WDYT?
If the approach suits correct for you, I will do the job for these 4 methods ofp `FileAssert`  : 
```
- isDirectoryRecursivelyContaining(String syntaxAndPattern)
- isDirectoryRecursivelyNotContaining(String syntaxAndPattern)
- isDirectoryRecursivelyContaining(Predicate<File> filter)
- isDirectoryRecursivelyNotContaining(Predicate<File> filter)
```

And just for the record, it seems that `PathAssert` the Path counterpart of `FileAssert` should probably be enriched with these new methods to keep the two Assert API consistent. Let' see that later.

> I will do the job for these 4 methods ofp FileAssert :

The 4 methods are needed for consistency, yes.
They should also be added to path assertions but in another PR to keep the PR to a reasonable size.
One thing you can do is implement one of the method and notify me when it is done, I can then review it. This will give guidance for the remaining methods to write and less work for both of us (general review comments won't have to be addressed four times, once the first is right and then do the others the same way)

> In assert methods I will add, for example `assertIsDirectoryRecursivelyContaining()`, in order to prevent iterate files more than required and to keep the code simple, I would like to favor `Files.walk(actual.toPath())` to some recursive call to `File.listFiles(FileFilter)`

I'm fine with that and like the functional style of the example!

@joel-costigliola

You probably didn't see my edit. Sorry, the next time I would add another comment instead of.
I indeed missed it! I'll think about it and get back to you. (ping me if I don't by the end of the week)

@ebundy sorry for the late reply, about the testing approach could we simply create any needed directories per tests? Although experimental we can leverage JUnit 5 [TempDir extension](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/current/api/org.junit.jupiter.api/org/junit/jupiter/api/io/TempDir.html). 
WDYT?
